C-D: 2 byte sequence start

8-B: Trail byte in a multi-byte sequence

1113632035283673088.text: Context: In my spare time I'm prototyping a PHP web application that will let Jeff Bezos securely share images with his friends.

1113630884756770818.text: If not, what am I missing?

1113630828410486784.text: Is there a standard web framework or design pattern for encrypting data at the client that is intended for consumption by a backend system (as opposed to the frontend)?

1113630793652301824.text: Everyone understands the benefit of pervasive HTTPS.  But it seems odd when you realize it only secures a direct connection to the least trusted server-side component -- the frontend web server.

1108850196190892032.text: How long before being good at video games requires surgery?https://twitter.com/ID_AA_Carmack/status/1108525750473367553 …

1108248742820339712.text: 12/ I guess the moral of the story is...  It’s probably more complicated than one developer not having seen something that seems obvious in retrospect.

1108248629934845953.text: 11/ Finally, consider that VBScript.Encode is this weird thing that popped up at some random point over a decade ago.  Independent of that other old / weird thing that is VBScript.

1108248564986048512.text: 10/ And the VBScript mitigation would need to fail open, as VBScript has to function normally in other environments that are not Internet Zone IE.

1108248466713505792.text: 9/ Then having VBScript.Encode effectively acting as a proxy is going to cause that to fail.  Also hard to predict without remembering VBScript.Encode.

1108248395766878211.text: 8/ Or maybe the mitigation is in VBScript itself, which could potentially check the zone of whatever hosts it.

1108248315789926400.text: 7/  In that case, if code in the host just were to check the CLSID or language, then it's going to miss VBScript.Encode.  Hard to predict when few even remember VBScript.Encode is a thing.

1108248248479735808.text: 6/  Maybe this mitigation is dependent on the VBScript CLSID as verified in the host.  (Though that seems problematic because there are many hosts...)

1108248169211551744.text: 5/ But back to the VBScript mitigation…  Surely someone did spend time building this thoughtfully.  I don’t see a problem with their thought process, it's just sometimes tough to predict variants in the matrix of mashup insanity that is IE.

1108248073224876032.text: 4/ ...because the mitigations may depend on something asking its host a question that the wrong host doesn't know how to answer properly.  (Or the wiring is broken & the check fails insecure by default.)

1108247993709268992.text: 3/ VBScript is not unique in this regard.  Go look at all the various MSHTML CLSIDs and imagine mashing them up with the array of different mitigations which may or may not apply properly inside of them.

1108247878873432064.text: 2/ The history of IE mitigations / vuln fixes is littered with issues like this.  In so many aspects of IE, there are just a whole bunch of vectors to doing exactly the same thing.

891035294719295488.text: 20/ I think that's the most reasonable mindset -- Mitigate now, move to secure-by-default over time.

891035141455306753.text: 19/ All this being said, it'd be great to see platforms evolve to be secure-by-default.

891034867193888768.text: 18/ So is it OK or in some way bad for security?  And if it's OK, why is this somehow different from other CSP mitigation functionality?

891034494722916352.text: 17/ Is this bad because it's a mitigation?  Is it fundamentally circumventable?  It's certainly not isolation.  Nor is it secure-by-default.

891033783696109568.text: 16/ Thought experiment -- How about a CSP feature that universally disables some particular unsafe construct (like IE expressions in CSS).

891033533757530112.text: 15/ The "isolation" vs. "mitigation" concept also slices things the wrong way.  It's somewhat arbitrary, and certainly not pragmatic.

891033284783726592.text: 14/ With so many crap JS libraries out there, discouraging actual innovative security work should be on the bottom of any todo list.

891033060761714688.text: 13/ Not great if we want to actually solve a problem.  I think if we're antagonizing DOMPurify, that's barking up the wrong tree...

891032811167031297.text: 12/ Make it difficult for app developers to secure their code and you'll get... insecure code.  (Surprise?)

891032527443337216.text: 11/ We shouldn't discourage the development of new mitigations that could be deployed to solve real-world problems here in 2017.

891032103709622273.text: 10/ If a mail app sanitizer can be circumvented, that's an absolutely massive vulnerability.

891031819679694848.text: 9/ There's no way to handwave that away, implying bypass is simple / pervasive.

891031525872893952.text: 8/ If sanitization is fundamentally circumventable, that should be demonstrated so the affected sanitizer(s) can be fixed.

891031271350063104.text: 7/ Not sure how close we are to getting mail clients to stop sanitizing markup in favor of isolation.  I think the answer is "not close."

891031017909174278.text: 6/ Sanitization prevents mail messages from running arbitrary code in the origin of your mail app.  Today.  For everybody.

891030517432238080.text: 4/ Now there is an assertion that this tool, by virtue of being labeled a mitigation, is fundamentally circumventable.

891030385164812288.text: 3/ Assume it handles charsets properly, etc.

891030299915636741.text: 2/ Take HTML sanitizers as an example.  Suppose we have a safe sanitizer that only allows <b> and standard or properly HTMLEncoded text.

891030174006890496.text: 1/ The idea that security mitigations on the whole are somehow fundamentally flawed is hard for me to accept.

891029777913593856.text: I still have a difference of opinion re the conclusions tho.  =)  Commencing tweetstorm in 3...  2...  1...
